segment.source: Create a Microsoft Passport login app
segment.target: Create a Microsoft Passport login app

segment.source: This is Part 1 of a complete walkthrough on how to create a Windows 10 UWP (Universal Windows Platform) app that uses Microsoft Passport as an alternative to traditional username and password authentication systems.
segment.target: This is Part 1 of a complete walkthrough on how to create a Windows 10 UWP (Universal Windows Platform) app that uses Microsoft Passport as an alternative to traditional username and password authentication systems.

segment.source: Create a Microsoft Passport login app
segment.target: Create a Microsoft Passport login app

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: \[Some information relates to pre-released product which may be substantially modified before it's commercially released.
segment.target: \[Some information relates to pre-released product which may be substantially modified before it's commercially released.

segment.source: Microsoft makes no warranties, express or implied, with respect to the information provided here.\]
segment.target: Microsoft makes no warranties, express or implied, with respect to the information provided here.\]

segment.source: This is Part 1 of a complete walkthrough on how to create a Windows 10 UWP (Universal Windows Platform) app that uses Microsoft Passport as an alternative to traditional username and password authentication systems.
segment.target: This is Part 1 of a complete walkthrough on how to create a Windows 10 UWP (Universal Windows Platform) app that uses Microsoft Passport as an alternative to traditional username and password authentication systems.

segment.source: The app uses a username for sign-in and create a Passport Key for each account.
segment.target: The app uses a username for sign-in and create a Passport Key for each account.

segment.source: These accounts will be protected by the PIN that is setup in Windows Settings on configuration of Microsoft Passport.
segment.target: These accounts will be protected by the PIN that is setup in Windows Settings on configuration of Microsoft Passport.

segment.source: This walkthrough is split into two parts: building the app and connecting the backend service.
segment.target: This walkthrough is split into two parts: building the app and connecting the backend service.

segment.source: When you're finished with this article, continue on to Part 2: Microsoft Passport login service.
segment.target: When you're finished with this article, continue on to Part 2: Microsoft Passport login service.

segment.source: Before you begin, you should read the Microsoft Passport and Windows Hello overview for a general understanding of how Microsoft Passport works.
segment.target: Before you begin, you should read the Microsoft Passport and Windows Hello overview for a general understanding of how Microsoft Passport works.

segment.source: Get started
segment.target: Get started

segment.source: In order to build this project, you'll need some experience with C#, and XAML.
segment.target: In order to build this project, you'll need some experience with C#, and XAML.

segment.source: You'll also need to be using Visual Studio 2015 (Community Edition or greater) on a Windows 10 machine.
segment.target: You'll also need to be using Visual Studio 2015 (Community Edition or greater) on a Windows 10 machine.

segment.source: Open Visual Studio 2015 and select File > New > Project.
segment.target: Open Visual Studio 2015 and select File > New > Project.

segment.source: This will open a “New Project” window.
segment.target: This will open a “New Project” window.

segment.source: Navigation to Templates > Visual C#.
segment.target: Navigation to Templates > Visual C#.

segment.source: Choose Blank App (Universal Windows) and name your application "PassportLogin".
segment.target: Choose Blank App (Universal Windows) and name your application "PassportLogin".

segment.source: Build and Run the new application (F5), you should see a blank window shown on the screen.
segment.target: Build and Run the new application (F5), you should see a blank window shown on the screen.

segment.source: Close the application.
segment.target: Close the application.

segment.source: Exercise 1: Login with Microsoft Passport
segment.target: Exercise 1: Login with Microsoft Passport

segment.source: In this exercise you will learn how to check if Microsoft Passport is setup on the machine, and how to sign into an account using Microsoft Passport.
segment.target: In this exercise you will learn how to check if Microsoft Passport is setup on the machine, and how to sign into an account using Microsoft Passport.

segment.source: In the new project create a new folder in the solution called "Views".
segment.target: In the new project create a new folder in the solution called "Views".

segment.source: This folder will contain the pages that will be navigated to in this sample.
segment.target: This folder will contain the pages that will be navigated to in this sample.

segment.source: Right click on the project in solution explorer, select Add > New Folder, then rename the folder to Views.
segment.target: Right click on the project in solution explorer, select Add > New Folder, then rename the folder to Views.

segment.source: Right click on the new Views folder, select Add > New Item and select Blank Page.
segment.target: Right click on the new Views folder, select Add > New Item and select Blank Page.

segment.source: Name this page "Login.xaml".
segment.target: Name this page "Login.xaml".

segment.source: To define the user interface for the new login page, add the following XAML.
segment.target: To define the user interface for the new login page, add the following XAML.

segment.source: This XAML defines a StackPanel to align the following children:
segment.target: This XAML defines a StackPanel to align the following children:

segment.source: TextBlock that will contain a title.
segment.target: TextBlock that will contain a title.

segment.source: TextBlock for error messages.
segment.target: TextBlock for error messages.

segment.source: TextBox for the username to input.
segment.target: TextBox for the username to input.

segment.source: Button to navigate to a register page.
segment.target: Button to navigate to a register page.

segment.source: TextBlock to contain the status of Microsoft Passport.
segment.target: TextBlock to contain the status of Microsoft Passport.

segment.source: TextBlock to explain the Login page as there is no backend or configured users.
segment.target: TextBlock to explain the Login page as there is no backend or configured users.

segment.source: A few methods need to be added to the code behind to get the solution building.
segment.target: A few methods need to be added to the code behind to get the solution building.

segment.source: Either press F7 or use the Solution Explorer to get to the Login.xaml.cs.
segment.target: Either press F7 or use the Solution Explorer to get to the Login.xaml.cs.

segment.source: Add in the following two event methods to handle the Login and Register events.
segment.target: Add in the following two event methods to handle the Login and Register events.

segment.source: For now these methods will set the ErrorMessage.Text to an empty string.
segment.target: For now these methods will set the ErrorMessage.Text to an empty string.

segment.source: In order to render the Login page, edit the MainPage code to navigate to the Login page when the MainPage is loaded.
segment.target: In order to render the Login page, edit the MainPage code to navigate to the Login page when the MainPage is loaded.

segment.source: Open the MainPage.xaml.cs file.
segment.target: Open the MainPage.xaml.cs file.

segment.source: In the solution explorer double click on MainPage.xaml.cs.
segment.target: In the solution explorer double click on MainPage.xaml.cs.

segment.source: If you can’t find this click the little arrow next to MainPage.xaml to show the code behind.
segment.target: If you can’t find this click the little arrow next to MainPage.xaml to show the code behind.

segment.source: Create a loaded event handler method that will navigate to the login page.
segment.target: Create a loaded event handler method that will navigate to the login page.

segment.source: You will need to add a reference to the Views namespace.
segment.target: You will need to add a reference to the Views namespace.

segment.source: In the Login page you need to handle the OnNavigatedTo event to validate if Microsoft Passport is available on this machine.
segment.target: In the Login page you need to handle the OnNavigatedTo event to validate if Microsoft Passport is available on this machine.

segment.source: In Login.xaml.cs implement the following.
segment.target: In Login.xaml.cs implement the following.

segment.source: You will notice that the MicrosoftPassportHelper object flags an error.
segment.target: You will notice that the MicrosoftPassportHelper object flags an error.

segment.source: This is because we have not implement it yet.
segment.target: This is because we have not implement it yet.

segment.source: To create the MicrosoftPassportHelper class, right click on the solution PassportLogin (Universal Windows) and click Add > New Folder.
segment.target: To create the MicrosoftPassportHelper class, right click on the solution PassportLogin (Universal Windows) and click Add > New Folder.

segment.source: Name this folder Utils.
segment.target: Name this folder Utils.

segment.source: Right click on the Utils folder and click Add > Class.
segment.target: Right click on the Utils folder and click Add > Class.

segment.source: Name this class "MicrosoftPassportHelper.cs".
segment.target: Name this class "MicrosoftPassportHelper.cs".

segment.source: Change the class definition of MicrosoftPassportHelper to public static, then add the following method that to inform the user if Microsoft Passport is ready to be used or not.
segment.target: Change the class definition of MicrosoftPassportHelper to public static, then add the following method that to inform the user if Microsoft Passport is ready to be used or not.

segment.source: You will need to add the required namespaces.
segment.target: You will need to add the required namespaces.

segment.source: In Login.xaml.cs add a reference to the Utils namespace.
segment.target: In Login.xaml.cs add a reference to the Utils namespace.

segment.source: This will resolve the error in the OnNavigatedTo method.
segment.target: This will resolve the error in the OnNavigatedTo method.

segment.source: Build and run the application (F5).
segment.target: Build and run the application (F5).

segment.source: You will be navigated to the login page and the Microsoft Passport banner will indicate to you if Passport is ready to be used.
segment.target: You will be navigated to the login page and the Microsoft Passport banner will indicate to you if Passport is ready to be used.

segment.source: You should see either the green or blue banner indicating the Microsoft Passport status on your machine.
segment.target: You should see either the green or blue banner indicating the Microsoft Passport status on your machine.

segment.source: The next thing you need to do is build the logic for signing in.
segment.target: The next thing you need to do is build the logic for signing in.

segment.source: Create a new folder called "Models".
segment.target: Create a new folder called "Models".

segment.source: In the Models folder create a new class called "Account.cs".
segment.target: In the Models folder create a new class called "Account.cs".

segment.source: This class will act as your account model.
segment.target: This class will act as your account model.

segment.source: As this is a sample it will only contain a username.
segment.target: As this is a sample it will only contain a username.

segment.source: Change the class definition to public and add the Username property.
segment.target: Change the class definition to public and add the Username property.

segment.source: You will need a way to handle accounts.
segment.target: You will need a way to handle accounts.

segment.source: For this hands on lab as there is no server, or a database, a list of users will be saved and loaded locally.
segment.target: For this hands on lab as there is no server, or a database, a list of users will be saved and loaded locally.

segment.source: Right click on the Utils folder and add a new class called "AccountHelper.cs".
segment.target: Right click on the Utils folder and add a new class called "AccountHelper.cs".

segment.source: Change the class definition to be public static.
segment.target: Change the class definition to be public static.

segment.source: The AccountHelper is a static class that will contain all the necessary methods to save and load the list of accounts locally.
segment.target: The AccountHelper is a static class that will contain all the necessary methods to save and load the list of accounts locally.

segment.source: Saving and loading will work by using an XmlSerializer.
segment.target: Saving and loading will work by using an XmlSerializer.

segment.source: You will also need to remember the file you saved and where you saved it.
segment.target: You will also need to remember the file you saved and where you saved it.

segment.source: Additional namespaces will be need to be referenced.
segment.target: Additional namespaces will be need to be referenced.

segment.source: Next, implement a way to add and remove an account from the local list of accounts.
segment.target: Next, implement a way to add and remove an account from the local list of accounts.

segment.source: These actions will each save the list.
segment.target: These actions will each save the list.

segment.source: The final method that you will need for this hands on lab is a validation method.
segment.target: The final method that you will need for this hands on lab is a validation method.

segment.source: As there is no auth server or database of users, this will validate against a single user which is hard coded.
segment.target: As there is no auth server or database of users, this will validate against a single user which is hard coded.

segment.source: These methods should be added to the AccountHelper class.
segment.target: These methods should be added to the AccountHelper class.

segment.source: The next thing you need to do is handle a sign in request from the user.
segment.target: The next thing you need to do is handle a sign in request from the user.

segment.source: In Login.xaml.cs create a new private variable that will hold the current account logging in.
segment.target: In Login.xaml.cs create a new private variable that will hold the current account logging in.

segment.source: Then add a new method call SignInPassport.
segment.target: Then add a new method call SignInPassport.

segment.source: This will validate the account credentials using the AccountHelper.ValidateAccountCredentials method.
segment.target: This will validate the account credentials using the AccountHelper.ValidateAccountCredentials method.

segment.source: This method will return a Boolean value if the entered user name is the same as the hard coded string value you set in the previous step.
segment.target: This method will return a Boolean value if the entered user name is the same as the hard coded string value you set in the previous step.

segment.source: The hard coded value for this sample is "sampleUsername".
segment.target: The hard coded value for this sample is "sampleUsername".

segment.source: You may have noticed the commented code that was referencing a method in MicrosoftPassportHelper.
segment.target: You may have noticed the commented code that was referencing a method in MicrosoftPassportHelper.

segment.source: In MicrosoftPassportHelper.cs add in a new method called CreatePassportKeyAsync.
segment.target: In MicrosoftPassportHelper.cs add in a new method called CreatePassportKeyAsync.

segment.source: This method uses the Microsoft Passport API in the KeyCredentialManager.
segment.target: This method uses the Microsoft Passport API in the KeyCredentialManager.

segment.source: Calling RequestCreateAsync will create a Passport key that is specific to the accountId and the local machine.
segment.target: Calling RequestCreateAsync will create a Passport key that is specific to the accountId and the local machine.

segment.source: Please note the comments in the switch statement if you are interested in implementing this in a real world scenario.
segment.target: Please note the comments in the switch statement if you are interested in implementing this in a real world scenario.

segment.source: Now you have created the CreatePassportKeyAsync method, return to the Login.xaml.cs file and uncomment the code inside the SignInPassport method.
segment.target: Now you have created the CreatePassportKeyAsync method, return to the Login.xaml.cs file and uncomment the code inside the SignInPassport method.

segment.source: Build and run the application.
segment.target: Build and run the application.

segment.source: You will be taken to the Login page.
segment.target: You will be taken to the Login page.

segment.source: Type in "sampleUsername" and click login.
segment.target: Type in "sampleUsername" and click login.

segment.source: You will be prompted with a Microsoft Passport prompt asking you to enter your PIN.
segment.target: You will be prompted with a Microsoft Passport prompt asking you to enter your PIN.

segment.source: Upon entering your PIN correctly the CreatePassportKeyAsync method will be able to create a Passport key.
segment.target: Upon entering your PIN correctly the CreatePassportKeyAsync method will be able to create a Passport key.

segment.source: Monitor the output windows to see if the messages saying successful are shown.
segment.target: Monitor the output windows to see if the messages saying successful are shown.

segment.source: Exercise 2: Welcome and User Selection Pages
segment.target: Exercise 2: Welcome and User Selection Pages

segment.source: In this exercise, you will continue from the previous exercise.
segment.target: In this exercise, you will continue from the previous exercise.

segment.source: When a person successfully logs in they should be taken to a welcome page where they can sign out or delete their account.
segment.target: When a person successfully logs in they should be taken to a welcome page where they can sign out or delete their account.

segment.source: As Passport creates a key for every machine, a user selection screen can be created, which displays all users that have been signed in on that machine.
segment.target: As Passport creates a key for every machine, a user selection screen can be created, which displays all users that have been signed in on that machine.

segment.source: A user can then select one of these accounts and go directly to the welcome screen without needed to re-enter a password as they have already authenticated to access the machine.
segment.target: A user can then select one of these accounts and go directly to the welcome screen without needed to re-enter a password as they have already authenticated to access the machine.

segment.source: In the Views folder add a new blank page called "Welcome.xaml".
segment.target: In the Views folder add a new blank page called "Welcome.xaml".

segment.source: Add the following XAML to complete the user interface.
segment.target: Add the following XAML to complete the user interface.

segment.source: This will display a title, the logged in username, and two buttons.
segment.target: This will display a title, the logged in username, and two buttons.

segment.source: One of the buttons will navigate back to a user list (that you will create later), and the other button will handle forgetting this user.
segment.target: One of the buttons will navigate back to a user list (that you will create later), and the other button will handle forgetting this user.

segment.source: In the Welcome.xaml.cs code behind file, add a new private variable that will hold the account that is logged in.
segment.target: In the Welcome.xaml.cs code behind file, add a new private variable that will hold the account that is logged in.

segment.source: You will need to implement a method to override the OnNavigateTo event, this will store the account passed to the welcome page.
segment.target: You will need to implement a method to override the OnNavigateTo event, this will store the account passed to the welcome page.

segment.source: You will also need to implement the click event for the two buttons defined in the XAML.
segment.target: You will also need to implement the click event for the two buttons defined in the XAML.

segment.source: You will need a reference to the Models and Utils folders.
segment.target: You will need a reference to the Models and Utils folders.

segment.source: You may have noticed a line commented out in the forget user click event.
segment.target: You may have noticed a line commented out in the forget user click event.

segment.source: The account is being removed from your local list but currently there is no way to be removed from Passport.
segment.target: The account is being removed from your local list but currently there is no way to be removed from Passport.

segment.source: You need to implement a new method in MicrosoftPassportHelper.cs that will handle removing a Passport user.
segment.target: You need to implement a new method in MicrosoftPassportHelper.cs that will handle removing a Passport user.

segment.source: This method will use other Microsoft Passport API’s to open and delete the account.
segment.target: This method will use other Microsoft Passport API’s to open and delete the account.

segment.source: In the real world when you delete an account the server or database should be notified so the user database remains valid.
segment.target: In the real world when you delete an account the server or database should be notified so the user database remains valid.

segment.source: You will need a reference to the Models folder.
segment.target: You will need a reference to the Models folder.

segment.source: Back in Welcome.xaml.cs, uncomment the line that calls RemovePassportAccountAsync.
segment.target: Back in Welcome.xaml.cs, uncomment the line that calls RemovePassportAccountAsync.

segment.source: In the SignInPassport method (of Login.xaml.cs), once the CreatePassportKeyAsync is successful it should navigate to the Welcome screen and pass the Account.
segment.target: In the SignInPassport method (of Login.xaml.cs), once the CreatePassportKeyAsync is successful it should navigate to the Welcome screen and pass the Account.

segment.source: Build and run the application.
segment.target: Build and run the application.

segment.source: Login with "sampleUsername" and click login.
segment.target: Login with "sampleUsername" and click login.

segment.source: Enter your PIN and if successful you should be navigated to the welcome screen.
segment.target: Enter your PIN and if successful you should be navigated to the welcome screen.

segment.source: Try clicking forget user and monitor the output window to see if the user was deleted.
segment.target: Try clicking forget user and monitor the output window to see if the user was deleted.

segment.source: Notice that when the user is deleted you remain on the welcome page.
segment.target: Notice that when the user is deleted you remain on the welcome page.

segment.source: You will need to create a user selection page that the app can navigate to.
segment.target: You will need to create a user selection page that the app can navigate to.

segment.source: In the Views folder create a new blank page called "UserSelection.xaml" and add the following XAML to define the user interface.
segment.target: In the Views folder create a new blank page called "UserSelection.xaml" and add the following XAML to define the user interface.

segment.source: This page will contain a ListView that displays all the users in the local accounts list, and a Button that will navigate to the login page to allow the user to add another account.
segment.target: This page will contain a ListView that displays all the users in the local accounts list, and a Button that will navigate to the login page to allow the user to add another account.

segment.source: In UserSelection.xaml.cs implement the loaded method that will navigate to the login page if there are no accounts in the local list.
segment.target: In UserSelection.xaml.cs implement the loaded method that will navigate to the login page if there are no accounts in the local list.

segment.source: Also implement the SelectionChanged event for the ListView and a click event for the Button.
segment.target: Also implement the SelectionChanged event for the ListView and a click event for the Button.

segment.source: There are a few places in the app where you want to navigated to the UserSelection page.
segment.target: There are a few places in the app where you want to navigated to the UserSelection page.

segment.source: In MainPage.xaml.cs you should navigate to the UserSelection page instead of the Login page.
segment.target: In MainPage.xaml.cs you should navigate to the UserSelection page instead of the Login page.

segment.source: While you are in the loaded event in MainPage you will need to load the accounts list so that the UserSelection page can check if there are any accounts.
segment.target: While you are in the loaded event in MainPage you will need to load the accounts list so that the UserSelection page can check if there are any accounts.

segment.source: This will require changing the loaded method to be async and also adding a reference to the Utils folder.
segment.target: This will require changing the loaded method to be async and also adding a reference to the Utils folder.

segment.source: Next you will want to navigate to the UserSelection page from the Welcome page.
segment.target: Next you will want to navigate to the UserSelection page from the Welcome page.

segment.source: In both click events you should navigate back to the UserSelection page.
segment.target: In both click events you should navigate back to the UserSelection page.

segment.source: In the Login page you need code to log in to the account selected from the list in the UserSelection page.
segment.target: In the Login page you need code to log in to the account selected from the list in the UserSelection page.

segment.source: In OnNavigatedTo event store the account passed to the navigation.
segment.target: In OnNavigatedTo event store the account passed to the navigation.

segment.source: Start by adding a new private variable that will identify if the account is an existing account.
segment.target: Start by adding a new private variable that will identify if the account is an existing account.

segment.source: Then handle the OnNavigatedTo event.
segment.target: Then handle the OnNavigatedTo event.

segment.source: The SignInPassport method will need to be updated to sign in to the selected account.
segment.target: The SignInPassport method will need to be updated to sign in to the selected account.

segment.source: The MicrosoftPassportHelper will need another method to open the account with Passport, as the account already has a Passport key created for it.
segment.target: The MicrosoftPassportHelper will need another method to open the account with Passport, as the account already has a Passport key created for it.

segment.source: Implement the new method in MicrosoftPassportHelper.cs to sign in an existing user with passport.
segment.target: Implement the new method in MicrosoftPassportHelper.cs to sign in an existing user with passport.

segment.source: For information on each part of the code please read through the code comments.
segment.target: For information on each part of the code please read through the code comments.

segment.source: Update the SignInPassport method in Login.xaml.cs to handle the existing account.
segment.target: Update the SignInPassport method in Login.xaml.cs to handle the existing account.

segment.source: This will use the new method in the MicrosoftPassportHelper.cs.
segment.target: This will use the new method in the MicrosoftPassportHelper.cs.

segment.source: If successful the account will be signed in and the user navigated to the welcome screen.
segment.target: If successful the account will be signed in and the user navigated to the welcome screen.

segment.source: Build and run the application.
segment.target: Build and run the application.

segment.source: Login with "sampleUsername".
segment.target: Login with "sampleUsername".

segment.source: Type in your PIN and if successful you will be navigated to the Welcome screen.
segment.target: Type in your PIN and if successful you will be navigated to the Welcome screen.

segment.source: Click back to user list.
segment.target: Click back to user list.

segment.source: You should now see a user in the list.
segment.target: You should now see a user in the list.

segment.source: If you click on this Passport enables you to sign back in without having to re-enter any passwords etc.
segment.target: If you click on this Passport enables you to sign back in without having to re-enter any passwords etc.

segment.source: Exercise 3: Registering a new Passport user
segment.target: Exercise 3: Registering a new Passport user

segment.source: In this exercise you will be creating a new page that will create a new account with Passport.
segment.target: In this exercise you will be creating a new page that will create a new account with Passport.

segment.source: This will work similarly to how the Login page works.
segment.target: This will work similarly to how the Login page works.

segment.source: The Login page is implemented for an existing user that is migrating to use Passport.
segment.target: The Login page is implemented for an existing user that is migrating to use Passport.

segment.source: A PassportRegister page will create Passport registration for a new user.
segment.target: A PassportRegister page will create Passport registration for a new user.

segment.source: In the views folder create a new blank page called "PassportRegister.xaml".
segment.target: In the views folder create a new blank page called "PassportRegister.xaml".

segment.source: In the XAML add in the following to setup the user interface.
segment.target: In the XAML add in the following to setup the user interface.

segment.source: The interface here is similar to the Login page.
segment.target: The interface here is similar to the Login page.

segment.source: In the PassportRegister.xaml.cs code behind file implement a private Account variable and a click event for the register Button.
segment.target: In the PassportRegister.xaml.cs code behind file implement a private Account variable and a click event for the register Button.

segment.source: This will add a new local account and create a Passport key.
segment.target: This will add a new local account and create a Passport key.

segment.source: You need to navigate to this page from the Login page when register is clicked.
segment.target: You need to navigate to this page from the Login page when register is clicked.

segment.source: Build and run the application.
segment.target: Build and run the application.

segment.source: Try to register a new user.
segment.target: Try to register a new user.

segment.source: Then return to the user list and validate that you can select that user and login.
segment.target: Then return to the user list and validate that you can select that user and login.

segment.source: In this lab you have learned the essential skills you need to use the new Microsoft Passport API to authenticate existing users and create accounts for new users.
segment.target: In this lab you have learned the essential skills you need to use the new Microsoft Passport API to authenticate existing users and create accounts for new users.

segment.source: With this new knowledge you can start removing the need for users to remember passwords for your application, yet remain confident that your applications remain protected by user authentication.
segment.target: With this new knowledge you can start removing the need for users to remember passwords for your application, yet remain confident that your applications remain protected by user authentication.

segment.source: Windows 10 uses the Passport technology to support the biometrics login of Windows Hello.
segment.target: Windows 10 uses the Passport technology to support the biometrics login of Windows Hello.

segment.source: If you have been using a machine that supports Windows Hello you will have seen that this set of exercises already supports Windows Hello.
segment.target: If you have been using a machine that supports Windows Hello you will have seen that this set of exercises already supports Windows Hello.

segment.source: There is no extra work you as a developer need to do in order to support Windows Hello once you have implemented support for Microsoft Passport.
segment.target: There is no extra work you as a developer need to do in order to support Windows Hello once you have implemented support for Microsoft Passport.

segment.source: Related topics
segment.target: Related topics

segment.source: Microsoft Passport and Windows Hello
segment.target: Microsoft Passport and Windows Hello

segment.source: Microsoft Passport login service
segment.target: Microsoft Passport login service
